title: Tariffs to 'significantly' increase costs and disrupt US solar and energy storage - PV Tech
description:
Tariff costs are almost always paid by importers and passed on to buyers and end consumers through higher prices.
Solar PV Woodmac said that the current tariff regime would “significantly” increase costs in the US solar PV market.
“An increase in tariff levels will only worsen this premium US energy consumers need to pay to access renewable energy.
Woodmac’s “trade war” forecast (seen in graph above) would impose steep price increases on energy storage, in particular.
Yesterday, our sister site, Energy-storage.news, reported that Chinese firm Hithium and South Korean battery manufacturer LG Energy Solution had begun producing energy storage products in the US.
text:
Chris Seiple, vice chairman of Power and Renewables at Wood Mackenzie said: “In a business with 5-to-10-year planning cycles, not knowing what a project will cost next year or the year after is disruptive and causes massive uncertainty for US power industry participants.”

He continued: “As a result, we could see potential delays in project development and rising power purchase agreement (PPA) prices. We will definitely see impacts on power sector capital projects. The severity depends on what scenarios play out.”

Most of Donald Trump’s broad, “reciprocal” tariffs are paused until the start of July. The US Court of International Trade’s ruling that the president overstepped his authority in imposing the tariffs has been temporarily suspended by a federal appeals court. However, levies on steel imports have been imposed.

Tariff costs are almost always paid by importers and passed on to buyers and end consumers through higher prices.

Solar PV

Woodmac said that the current tariff regime would “significantly” increase costs in the US solar PV market. The US already receives some of the most expensive solar modules in the world, thanks to its historic trade barriers against China and changeable, sometimes eye-wateringly steep, antidumping and countervailing duty (AD/CVD) tariffs on products arriving from Southeast Asia.

Donald Trump’s “reciprocal” tariffs, and particularly tense trade relations with China, are set to make US solar even more expensive.

Under its “trade tensions” forecast, which assumes that the effective US tariff rate settles at 10% by the end of 2026, with a 34% rate on China, a US solar project will be 54% more expensive than in Europe and 85% more expensive than the same plant built in China.

Woodmac’s “trade war” forecast, where the US takes an aggressive tariff line, up to an overall rate of 30% through 2030, the construction cost of a solar project would increase by around 15%, compared with around 5% under the more measured “trade tensions” scenario.

“The tariffs that have been in place on solar modules along with an inefficient transmission policy that exacerbates interconnection costs have made construction costs for solar higher in the US than in most other markets,” said Seiple. “An increase in tariff levels will only worsen this premium US energy consumers need to pay to access renewable energy.

“While the full impact remains uncertain, it’s clear that industry participants need to prepare for increased costs and potential disruptions to their supply chains.”

Energy storage

Woodmac said that the US energy storage market would be hit much harder than any other power sector due to its exposure to China.

While China dominates global solar module production, the US has successfully built domestic manufacturing capacity and can source input products like cells and wafers from other regions of the world. By contrast, Woodmac said that “nearly all” battery cells used in US utility-scale storage projects in 2024 came from China.

The report estimates that cost increases for US utility-scale storage could range between 12% and 50%, depending on the severity of tariffs. Woodmac’s “trade war” forecast (seen in graph above) would impose steep price increases on energy storage, in particular.

Seiple said that, while US battery cell manufacturing is expanding, “it is not expanding at a pace nearly fast enough to meet even a small fraction of battery projects in the US.

“In 2025, we estimate there is sufficient domestic manufacturing capacity to only meet about 6% of demand and, by 2030, domestic manufacturing could potentially meet 40% of demand,” he continued.

Yesterday, our sister site, Energy-storage.news, reported that Chinese firm Hithium and South Korean battery manufacturer LG Energy Solution had begun producing energy storage products in the US. US battery gigafactories have already faced delays and cancellations amid the uncertainty brought about by Trump’s tariff regime; read more of that in a guest post on our sister site, here. (premium access)

A war on two fronts

As well as uncertainty and increased costs from tariffs, the US is facing the rollback of domestic incentives for clean energy deployments and manufacturing.

The US tax reconciliation bill, dubbed “One, Big, Beautiful Bill” by Donald Trump, currently proposes a near-cliff-edge end to Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) production and investment tax credits for renewable energy.

text:
Buyers continue to hesitate to consider an EV as their next vehicle, and at the lowest rate recorded since 2019, according to AAA’s latest survey.

Only 16% of U.S. adults report being “very likely” or “likely” to purchase a fully electric vehicle as their next car, according to the survey fielded in March.

The percentage of consumers who said they’d be “unlikely” or “very unlikely” to purchase an EV also rose from 51% to 63%, the highest since 2022.

“Since we began tracking interest in fully electric vehicles, we’ve seen some variability,” said Greg Brannon, AAA’s director of automotive engineering, in a press release. “While the automotive industry is committed to long-term electrification and providing a diverse range of models, underlying consumer hesitation remains.”

High battery repair costs (62%) and purchase price (59%) are cited as key barriers to going fully electric.

Other top concerns identified in this year’s survey were:

The perceived unsuitability of EVs for long-distance travel (57%);

A lack of convenient public charging stations (56%); and

The fear of running out of charge while driving (55%).

Thirty-one percent of those undecided or unlikely to buy an EV have safety concerns. Twenty-seven percent reported challenges installing charging stations at their homes, and 12% cited the potential reduction or elimination of tax credits and rebates.

According to AAA’s 2024 “Your Driving Cost” analysis, EVs had the second-highest total ownership costs due to depreciation, purchase prices, and finance charges.

In 2022, gas prices reached $5, prompting many Americans to consider transitioning to EVs. Of those AAA surveyed that year, 77% cited gas savings as their top motivation to purchase.

Now, the national average for a gallon of regular gas ranges from $3-$3.50, higher in some states, according to AAA.

This year, the primary reasons for buying EVs were similar: gas savings, environmental concerns, and anticipated lower maintenance costs of EVs.

According to last year’s “Your Driving Cost” analysis, EVs had the lowest “fuel” cost of any vehicle type, based on a national average electricity price of 15.9 cents per kilowatt hour (kWh). EVs also had the lowest maintenance costs among all models.

The percentage of U.S. drivers who believe that most cars will be electric within the next 10 years has significantly declined from 40% in 2022 to 23% this year. Interest in EVs to take advantage of tax credits and rebates has also decreased, dropping from 60% of those who said last year they were likely to buy an EV to 39% this year.

“Many consumers may find hybrid or plug-in hybrid vehicles more appealing,” AAA said. “These vehicles combine the advantages of traditional internal combustion engines with electric power, reducing range anxiety while providing an environmentally friendly alternative. This combination meets today’s diverse needs and preferences for drivers, allowing them to enjoy electric driving without losing the familiarity of conventional gas-powered vehicles.”

EV purchasing was up nationwide by year-end 2024, according to the Alliance for Automotive Innovation’s “Get Connected Electric Vehicle Quarterly Report 2024 (Q4).”

EVs represented 10.9% of new light-duty vehicle sales in Q4 2024, up from 10.6% in Q3 and 10.2% in Q4 2023. Light truck sales represent 81% of the EV market, up from 80% in Q3.

There are 5.8 million EVs on the road and 194,824 publicly available charging outlets in the U.S., meaning there are 30 EVs for every public port.

During Q4, four states had EV registrations above 20%, including Colorado (26.4%), California (26.2%), Washington (21.3%), and the District of Columbia (20.3%).

Nationwide, 433,843 EVs were registered in Q4 but only 9,701 new public chargers were added — a ratio of 45 new EVs for every new public port.

For full-year 2024, EVs made up 10.2% of new light-duty vehicle sales, up from 9.5% in 2023 and 7% in 2022.

name: EPA
title: Trump administration halting of EPA climate grants strands cities with urgent infrastructure needs
description:
Cities across the U.S. are losing millions in climate and health grants as the Trump administration cancels funding for projects once targeted to help vulnerable communities.
The EPA says the grants no longer align with the Trump administration’s priorities, part of a broader rollback of environmental justice initiatives that focused on disadvantaged communities.
Other Georgia cities, like Athens and Savannah, have had grants suspended or canceled, leaving local governments in limbo and financially strained after investing significant time and resources in the application process.
The rollback of EPA grants not only stalls urgent repairs but also threatens to deepen inequality, as smaller cities and nonprofits often lack the resources to replace lost federal funding.
And while some cities are trying to appeal, the uncertain status of these grants has real consequences: lost time, wasted money, and growing public health risks.
text:
Cities across the U.S. are losing millions in climate and health grants as the Trump administration cancels funding for projects once targeted to help vulnerable communities.

Emily Jones reports for Grist.

In short:

Thomasville, Georgia, lost a $19.8 million U.S. Environmental Protection Agency grant intended to modernize its failing wastewater system, build a health clinic, and improve historic homes after federal officials abruptly canceled the award in May.

The EPA says the grants no longer align with the Trump administration’s priorities, part of a broader rollback of environmental justice initiatives that focused on disadvantaged communities.

Other Georgia cities, like Athens and Savannah, have had grants suspended or canceled, leaving local governments in limbo and financially strained after investing significant time and resources in the application process.

Key quote:

“They are causing project costs to skyrocket because they keep freezing and unfreezing and refreezing projects.”

— Zealan Hoover, advisor to Environmental Protection Network and Lawyers for Good Government

Why this matters:

Local infrastructure may be unglamorous, but it’s foundational to public health and environmental protection — especially in communities already burdened by industrial pollution, poverty, and extreme weather. Wastewater systems, for example, keep untreated sewage out of homes and waterways, while resilience hubs and emergency power systems help protect residents during climate-fueled disasters. The rollback of EPA grants not only stalls urgent repairs but also threatens to deepen inequality, as smaller cities and nonprofits often lack the resources to replace lost federal funding. And while some cities are trying to appeal, the uncertain status of these grants has real consequences: lost time, wasted money, and growing public health risks.

Transcript

Introduction

[00:00:14] Michael Novogradac, CPA: Hello, I'm Michael Novogradac, and this is Tax Credit Tuesday. This is the June 3rd, 2025, podcast. I'm here today with my partner Tony Grappone, and this is our latest installment in our monthly renewable energy tax credit finance series. We do have a playlist of all episodes in this energy series on YouTube.

This is our 18th installment of that series. And today's episode is a follow up to an episode that we aired last year on prevailing wage and apprenticeship requirements for renewable energy tax credits, sometimes called PWA requirements. Now, our regular listeners may be wondering why we're so focused on prevailing wage and apprenticeship requirements when a bill has been passed by the House that would be very detrimental to the renewable energy tax credit community. Now we do expect the Senate to relax some of the House provisions. And if you want to know more about how disastrous the House bill would be to the renewable energy community, if it were to be enacted as passed in the House, I'd encourage you to listen to or watch the podcast that Peter Lawrence, our chief public policy officer, and I recorded last week.

I'd also encourage you to review our various blog posts. And I'd also encourage you to join if you're not already a member of the Renewable Energy Tax Credit Working Group, which Tony leads along with Peter Lawrence and our public policy team. And beyond that, I'd encourage you to do advocacy on behalf of renewable energy tax credits, particularly with the Senate, particularly with the Senate Finance Committee.

That said, we do expect there to be a robust investment tax credit market for several years to come. And to that end, we thought it was important to revisit the PWA or prevailing wage and apprenticeship requirements. And today's episode we'll go a little bit deeper on practical strategies to ensure you're complying with those rules.

We'll share some useful tips and strategies as well as some traps to avoid. Now, before I proceed, I wanted to share some background as to why PWA compliance is so important, and this is a bit of level setting. And please bear with me if you're very experienced and already know the answer to the question.

Now in the renewable energy space, our less frequent listeners may be thinking of the investment tax credit as a 30% tax credit. For years and years, it was a 30% tax credit. Then it decreased, a little bit each year as it was phasing out down to 26%. And back in 2022, the Inflation Reduction Act as a technical matter actually reduced the then 26% down to 6%.

Now, obviously we don't talk about a 6% credit. We talk about a 30% credit, and that's because the Inflation Reduction Act also enacted provisions that increase the credit rate to 30% if you satisfied certain prevailing wage and apprenticeship requirements. As a consequence. I mean, Tony, have you ever seen a 6% transaction?

No. No. Tony's shaking his head no. In case those of you that are listening and not watching on YouTube, so it's, everyone thinks about it as a 30% credit, and everyone thinks about it as you have apprenticeship and prevailing wage requirements that you need to satisfy. And to that end, Novogradac, with Tony's leadership and many others at Novogradac, we built a line of services tailored to satisfy investor due diligence requirements with respect to the PWA requirements.

And Tony and his team, as you know, work with many renewable energy developers and investors. And Tony will share his various tips on dos and don'ts for PWA compliance. Now we have a lot we want to cover today. So if you're ready, let's get started.

Conference Highlights and PWA Refresher

[00:04:30] Michael Novogradac, CPA: Tony, welcome back to Tax Credit Tuesday.

[00:04:36] Tony Grappone, CPA: Thanks, Mike.

It's always great to be here with you.

[00:04:39] Michael Novogradac, CPA: And it was great to see you in Chicago a few weeks ago at Novogradac 2025 Spring Renewable Energy Tax credit conference. And you know, as you, know, the conference kicked off just one day after the House Ways and Means Committee released their markup of the House reconciliation bill.

So there was no shortage of hot topics to talk about at the event about the damage that House bill would cause to clean energy.

[00:05:07] Tony Grappone, CPA: Yeah, indeed. I'll tell you, a lot of people come up to me at our renewable energy conferences, Mike, and they say, how do you guys time your events so well? So for some reason, I don't know how we do it, but coincidentally, we oftentimes our renewable energy conferences happen to take place at a time following some sort of major election or policy enactment or what have you, something that really impacts the industry from a legislative matter.

And so, yeah, the Washington Report panel that you moderated, as well as that policy discussion that you moderated with Jason Grumet, I mean. Those conversations were just so timely and had everybody on the edge of their seats. Somebody came up to me and said, you know, Mike's turned into like the E.F. Hutton of tax credit policy matters.

[00:05:54] Michael Novogradac, CPA: I think we're both dating ourselves with that reference.

[00:05:57] Tony Grappone, CPA: Right, right. We'll see how many listeners--

[00:05:59] Michael Novogradac, CPA: That you used it and I got it.

[00:06:02] Tony Grappone, CPA: Exactly. So, but no, the conference was an overall success. The timing couldn't have been better and I think a lot of people felt, all the attendees that were there said they're so, they were so glad to be there at that time to get all that excellent perspective on the House bill, you know, as it first got released. So, great timing.

Prevailing Wage Requirements

[00:06:20] Michael Novogradac, CPA: Great. Thank you for that. And, you know, one thing that I, well, actually before I ask you that question first, give a quick refresher on the prevail wage and apprenticeship rules, and then we'll go down, down a little bit deeper into each of those.

[00:06:34] Tony Grappone, CPA: Yeah. Great. Yep. So I'll cover this from high level.

As you pointed out, many of our listeners are sort of already familiar with some of the PWA rules, but for those of you who are new and there could be some folks here that aren't that familiar with it. And as we get through this podcast, I'll reveal some folks that this. This podcast really may appeal to, and those folks really may not be familiar with these rules at all.

And so it does make sense to kind of cover them, at least from a high level. All right, so first off, as you alluded to, the PWA requirements, you know, they first came into, for renewable energy tax credits they were never an issue until the Inflation Reduction Act was passed. Once the IRA was passed that require that, that requires taxpayers commencing construction on qualifying facilities after Jan. 28th, 2023, and facilities that are over one megawatt AC, those facilities are subject to this PWA criteria.

So now if you commenced construction before Jan. 29th, 2023, or if your facility is under one megawatt AC, then you're deemed to satisfy the PWA rules. Okay? Now these days, you know, we're not coming con, we're not coming across too many facilities that commenced construction before Jan. 29th, 2023, and we don't see too many facilities that are under one megawatt AC.

So you know, most facilities are subject to these rules if they want the higher tax credit percentage. So, but big picture, if you're subject to the PWA rules, then taxpayers are required to pay prevailing wages to all laborers performing construction and/or alteration of the facility. And they're also required to use apprentices for a minimum percentage of the hours to construct the facility.

Now, the PWA tax rules they provided for in final Treasury regulations that the IRS and Treasury published last June. And then for nuanced apprenticeship rules, those rules can be found in the applicable apprenticeship program guidelines for whichever apprenticeship program you're enrolled with.

[00:08:41] Michael Novogradac, CPA: Great.

Thank you for that overview. And there's probably a listener or viewer or two that are wondering, while we're not going into depth on this podcast, about the House bill and the damage it would cause to the clean energy community. They're probably wondering, does the House bill change at all the PWA requirements?

There was some talk that maybe the PWA requirements would be changed by House and or Senate Republicans.

[00:09:10] Tony Grappone, CPA: Right, right. So leading up to the House bill being passed, there was some speculation that maybe that House bill would change the way the PWE rules are, whether they apply at all or how they're, or how they're enforced.

We haven't seen that in the House bill. You know, maybe something does happen on the Senate side, but as of now, you know, we don't anticipate any changes to the PWA rules with respect to these tax credit percentages.

[00:09:33] Michael Novogradac, CPA: Great. Thank you for that. Now when we talk about prevailing wage and apprenticeship requirements, let's talk about them as two.

They're two separate requirements, but you know, both need to be satisfied. And before I ask you about the various services that you provide in each of those areas, can you first talk about when you recommend that you get engaged to provide the various services you provide to avoid failing to satisfy the requirements or committing foot faults?

[00:10:05] Tony Grappone, CPA: Yeah. Great. So we've, we have a bunch of PWA engagements in progress right now. We have many where we've been hired at the end of construction, we have several where we got engaged midway through construction. Right. And then we also have several where we got engaged before construction commenced.

If possible, I always recommend clients engage us before construction commences because if we're able to perform, you know, our analysis as construction progresses, then we can identify potential issues earlier on, which can then help clients kind of course correct. And if they can course correct timely enough, they can avoid costly, you know, penalties and corrective payments that may come up if you, if we're engaged kind of late or after construction's done.

[00:10:57] Michael Novogradac, CPA: And that's certainly a theme of this podcast and all the various areas where we provide services earlier is always better. And the longer you wait, the harder it can be to correct issues that get identified. You know, that being said, you definitely want to identify them as soon as possible, even know if it's later in the process.

Because, you know, you know, there, you know, time always allows the earlier it's found, the greater options you have. So let's start with prevailing wages and then we'll talk about apprenticeship requirements. So let's start with prevailing wages and tell our audience what the services are that you provide to help developers comply with various investor due diligence requirements and get a certain level of comfort as to their own compliance.

[00:11:46] Tony Grappone, CPA: Great. All right. So first off, I'll just note that the IRS doesn't require a third-party to review a prevailing wage and apprenticeship compliance profile. That being said, most investors in the marketplace do, as a condition precedent to financing, require a third party like Novogradac to perform diligence to analyze the PWA profile of a facility before they'll fund money.

And some tax insurance providers can also require that or tax credit buyers.

[00:12:20] Michael Novogradac, CPA: And I would just note that's much like historic tax credits. Investors will require a cost certification. You know, the low-income housing tax credit there is one required for state agencies. So there, it's a state agency requirement as well as an investor requirement, but it's quite common across all the various tax credits for investors to identify these cliff effect sorts of issues and want some degree of external assurance.

[00:12:46] Tony Grappone, CPA: Exactly. That's right. So we're usually doing this because an investor requires it. We do have some situations where just the developer is building a project on their own, doesn't have an outside investor, they're just kind of paranoid or nervous, or they just want to make sure they've got their ducks in a row.

So they just hire us without that sort of investor requirement. But anyway, just the big point is it's not an IRS requirement for third-party diligence. It's usually a, it usually comes into play because of a financing requirement. All right. So yeah, I, now let's unpack that a bit. I like how you focused on prevailing wages.

So I, that's how we approach it. We sort of think of prevailing wage testing as separate from the apprenticeship-style testing. So when we get engaged to help a client, we're usually getting engaged pursuant to what's called an agreed-upon procedures engagement. That's a classic type of engagement that investors like when they're looking for some third-party help to analyze some ty, some type of tax compliance matter.

Okay. So we perform the service pursuant to an agreed upon procedures engagement, and then for prevailing wage testing, what we're doing a lot of there is we're looking at what's called certified payroll records. We're taking certified payroll records from the taxpayer that owns the facility and oftentimes they're outsourcing that work to various contractors and subcontractors.

But anyway, we're looking at the certified payroll records from the employers of the laborers that are doing the construction of the facility. We're looking at the hours they worked, their job classifications, pay rates, and then we're comparing those, the amounts that they were paid to the minimum amounts that, that they were required to be paid based off of the prevailing wages as published by the Department of Labor.

Okay? So we analyze what they were paid against, and then we do a recalculation of what the minimum they were required to be paid during any pay period. And a pay period is usually a week. Okay. And so we'll do that for every laborer, for every pay period of every contractor throughout the whole entire construction period.

And we will identify, if we observe any situations of corrective payments necessary. A corrective payment would be necessary if in any pay period they were, you had a worker that was underpaid compared to what they were required to be paid.

[00:14:59] Michael Novogradac, CPA: So what are some of the common issues? You just mentioned one there, if a work, you identify a worker being underpaid.

Are there other issues that you commonly confront as you approach this analysis?

[00:15:14] Tony Grappone, CPA: Right. Yeah, exactly. So a common issue we can encounter is with respect to clarity on the certified payroll records. Okay. Couple of examples. One example might be a job classification that isn't particularly clear or explicit in terms of what their required pay rate is. That's one of, that's one example. Another example, a classic example, is with respect to fringe benefits. We see some certified payroll records where the fringe benefits, where there's some, where all fringe benefits are included on the certified payroll record. And when I say all fringe benefits, I'm talking about cash fringe benefits that are paid directly to the employee versus non-cash fringe benefits such as pension payments. Okay. We've seen certified payroll records that reveal all that information, and we've seen certified payroll records where some portion of the fringe benefits are paid outside the certified payroll records.

The issue that can create is if the, if we're looking at the certified payroll record and we're using that as the documentation as far as what the laborer was paid, well, if that certified payroll record omits any portion of their compensation, like non-cash fringe, then that can lead to us getting the impression that maybe they were underpaid and need a corrective payment.

And so oftentimes we'll do our analysis and if we start to see a trend of perceived underpayments, we'll reach back to our clients. Say, are we getting the full picture here? Are there, is it possible you've got some other payments going to this laborer that's paid outside the certified payroll records?

So that's those are probably two examples. Lack of clarification with job classifications and certified payroll records that don't include some portion of the laborers' compensation.

[00:16:57] Michael Novogradac, CPA: So let's talk about the consequences of failing to qualify. I mentioned earlier that a developer needs to comply with these requirements in order to get the 30% credit instead of 6%.

You've already implied in your answers that the consequences of failing to qualify isn't necessarily that you have to claim a lower credit. It's that you have these payments that you need to make. So explain the consequences of failing the prevailing wage requirements.

[00:17:28] Tony Grappone, CPA: Right, right. So let's imagine that, lo and behold, there was a, there was an actual underpayment of a laborer during any pay period during the year.

If that happens, then the taxpayer is required to make a corrective payment to that laborer. And let's imagine they do that. If they make that corrective payment timely, they're still in compliance. They're still entitled to the 30% ITC. And if they make the corrective payment within certain time limits, then they can also avoid IRS penalties.

Now, let's imagine they make the corrective payment, but they don't discover the corrective payment soon enough to avoid IRS penalties, then they can end up in a situation where they're not only making a corrective payment to the laborer, but they're also making a $5,000 IRS penalty payment plus interest.

And so that time window is very important. The IRS allows you to avoid that IRS penalty if you make corrective payments by the 30th day following the quarter end. So if we're talking about Q1 of 2025, if you discover a corrective payment and you make that corrective payment on or before April 30th, 2025, then you'd avoid the $5,000 penalty.

So it's, that's another reason why, if a firm like ours is involved earlier on and we're monitoring the results, as construction progresses, we can help identify potential corrective payment so they can make it so they can be made in a timely fashion and avoid costly IRS penalties.

[00:19:03] Michael Novogradac, CPA: Is that $5,000 per failure?

[00:19:07] Tony Grappone, CPA: It, oh, great question. So it's, it's per laborer during the calendar year. So for example, let's say you had John Doe was underpaid, $1 in every pay period during the year, it would be one $5,000 penalty. Now, let's imagine John Doe was underpaid one pay period for a dollar. Jane Doe was also underpaid $1 in one pay period. Well, now you have two $5,000 penalties. One per worker.

[00:19:40] Michael Novogradac, CPA: Great. Thank you for that. Anything else you want to say on prevailing wage? Just should we turn to apprenticeship?

[00:19:45] Tony Grappone, CPA: That's sufficient for now. We can turn to apprenticeship.

Apprenticeship Requirements

[00:19:48] Michael Novogradac, CPA: So let's go to apprenticeship. Please share with our audience some of the work that you do through an AUP to document compliance with apprenticeship requirements.

[00:20:00] Tony Grappone, CPA: Great. So with apprenticeship testing, the penalties that come into play for apprenticeship, it's not really with respect to how much the apprentice was paid. It's more about the hours they worked. So with apprenticeship compliance, the taxpayer needs to ensure that a minimum percentage of the total construction hours were performed by apprentices.

Okay. Now the apprenticeship compliance testing is performed on a daily basis. You remember when I talked about prevailing wage testing, I was focusing on amounts paid per pay period, which is per week. When you get into apprenticeship testing, that's a daily test, and what you're looking at there is you're looking at the number of hours an apprentice worked, and you're comparing that to the number of hours that there was a journey worker on site to provide adequate supervision and support.

Okay. Now, if the apprentice, if you have a situation where an apprentice worked hours and they lacked the requisite journey worker supervision and support, then those hours where the apprentice worked without being adequately supervised or having access to adequate supervision, those hours cannot be counted towards your apprentice hours for meeting the minimum percentage test.

And this is where, when we see issue, this is the biggest issue we see when we do PWA testing. In general, if you have an apprentice that worked without adequate journey worker support, those hours are now recast as hours subject to prevailing wage payments. Okay. And so I have never seen a state apprenticeship program that requires apprentices to be paid as much as prevailing wages.

They always in, in my experience, the apprentices can always be paid at lower rates than prevailing wages. And so an example would be the state apprenticeship program might require taxpayer to pay apprentices $30 an hour. Okay. Now, if that same apprentice was a journey worker, the prevailing wage rate per the Department of Labor might be, say for example, $50 an hour.

So if an apprentice goes out to the site and works eight hours that day, now you had a journey worker that went out, started the day alongside the apprentice, worked until noon, but then let's just imagine the journey worker got sick and had to go home, but the apprentice continued to work the afternoon, another four hours.

Well, those four hours in the afternoon, the apprentice can't be paid just $30 an hour. They're now recast for payment purposes. They were required to be paid the prevailing wage of $50 an hour. This is a classic example of where a client or a taxpayer didn't realize that the journey worker went home early and that a corrective payment's now needed for that apprentice.

That's a situation we see get discovered too late, too often. And so the most common scenario that we see triggering corrective payments is with respect to apprentices that ended up getting recast as a journey worker for required payment purposes. That gives the IRS a corrective payment, as well as if it gets discovered too late an IRS penalty. Okay.

Consequences of Non-Compliance

[00:23:24] Michael Novogradac, CPA: Yes. No, that's very interesting and all the more reason to be looking at both at the same time and looking at it at the beginning. Definitely. So these situations can be avoided. So what's, what are the consequences of failing to qualify for the apprenticeship or with the apprenticeship rules?

[00:23:49] Tony Grappone, CPA: Great. All right, so with apprenticeship, so we've talked about the IRS penalties, the $5,000 IRS penalty per worker that comes into play when a journey worker is underpaid or when an apprentice got recharacterized as a journey worker for required payment purposes. Okay, but now let me talk about just the apprentice penalties themselves.

Okay? You've got two types of apprenticeship penalties. One is what's called a non-participation penalty. What that means is if you're an employer of laborers doing work on the site, and you're required to enroll in a registered apprenticeship program but you did not actually enroll in apprenticeship program, then you're deemed to not comply with the participation requirement.

Okay, and so when are you required to participate? If you have four or more laborers performing work on site, you're required to use at least one apprentice. Okay, so if you have four more labors, you don't, and you didn't enroll and you didn't participate, then you're subject to a $50 per hour penalty. And there's a formula that I could talk you through, but it's a bit involved, so I'll skip that.

But there is a formula, okay? The second type of apprenticeship penalty is pretty simple. The taxpayer is supposed to use apprentices for a minimum percentage of total construction hours. If you commence construction in 2024, that's 15%. Okay, so what we do is we do this analysis where we add up all the construction hours performed during the construction period.

We multiply that by 15%. That tells you your minimum, you know, target to get apprentice for of qualified apprentice hours. And at the end of the day, if they fell short, they pay a separate $50 per hour penalty for the shortfall on hours. Okay?

[00:25:46] Michael Novogradac, CPA: Yeah.

[00:25:47] Tony Grappone, CPA: And so we've seen situations where a client cut it too close.

They were just at the 15% sort of threshold. However, they didn't realize they had a few situations where the journey worker went home sick, so to speak. Okay. And then that kind of dropped 'em underneath the sort of minimum bar.

[00:26:07] Michael Novogradac, CPA: Got it. And is there a recommendation that you give to clients? To say, well, don't cut the 50% too close. Is there a any sort of standard cushion or what's your general advice to clients with respect to that 15%?

[00:26:23] Tony Grappone, CPA: Yeah, it's, I definitely recommend they build in some, we what, when we see, you know, add like 5%, something like that. Like give a little bit of cushion there. Assume that you'll have some scenarios where the journey workers just won't be able to provide adequate support in certain days based on extenuating circumstances.

So just kind of round up a bit there. The other thing they can do is, again, if we get involved earlier on, we can help monitor how they're doing in terms of like reaching their target, right? And so when we're engaged earlier on, we'll keep. We'll ask them for their total budget of construction hours.

And so every month we're able to see how close they're getting to meeting their target. And if we observe that they're like really far behind, we can let them know because they, you have a lot of catch up to do here on the apprenticeship testing.

[00:27:05] Michael Novogradac, CPA: Yeah, it seems like the general approach would be to not get yourself in that situation. And ensure that you have an adequate ratio of journey workers to apprentices so that if one journey worker is unavailable.

[00:27:24] Tony Grappone, CPA: Yeah. I'll give you another example too because oftentimes you have like an EPC. An EPC is synonymous with like general contractor in the real estate world.

So you have like an EPC and then the EPC will sub out various tasks to a variety of subcontractors. Okay. Some subcontractors might represent to the EPC, they'll say, look, we don't anticipate having four more laborers, so we don't have to use apprentices. Okay? But then—

[00:27:53] Michael Novogradac, CPA: Lo and behold, I know where this is headed.

[00:27:56] Tony Grappone, CPA: They add that fourth or whatever the other one. The other thing too is there is what's known as a good faith effort exception. So if you're a subcontractor and you're located in an area. If you reach out to the apprenticeship program, you say, you know, we're an electrical sub, we need, apprentices, do you have any, please let us know.

If the apprenticeship program writes back and says, thanks for reaching out, we don't have any apprentices, then that qualifies for what's called a good faith effort exception. Okay. But to really set, to really meet the criteria of the good faith effort exception you're supposed to do, you're supposed to reach out to them in a certain timeframe, in a certain manner. Be very, include specifics about the facility. And so one thing that we'll see is an EPC will say, you know, X, Y, Z subcontractor meets the, told us they have a good faith effort exception. Okay. And we'll say, okay, wonderful. We'll need to, you know, can they provide the documentation? And then when we see the documentation, we've seen situations where that subcontractor reached out to the wrong apprenticeship program, didn't include the criteria, asked too late. Anyway, a variety of things where they don't actually check all the requisite IRS boxes in terms of meeting the good faith effort exception. So that can also, you might have an EPC that just assumes, oh, my subcontractor met the good faith effort exception, so we're all good here. And then lo and behold, they do not.

[00:29:17] Michael Novogradac, CPA: And what percentage of projects would you say rely on that exception? And how do investors feel about that exception versus documenting compliance with the apprenticeship rules?

[00:29:31] Tony Grappone, CPA: You know, some, sometimes if you've got a facility that's located in a particularly like rural area and you've got a well organized EPC or subcontractor that timely reaches out and so forth, then that good faith effort exception can really be a bonafide good faith effort exception.

What we find though, is it's, you might have a subcontractor that almost every facility has some small sub where they only had a few workers or whatever. And so they, they're not required to use it because too few laborers or you'll have at least one sub that claims they reached out to get a good faith effort exception.

You're going to, you're going to encounter it. And it just comes down to the quality of the paperwork and the manner in which they sought it out.

Closing Remarks

[00:30:14] Michael Novogradac, CPA: No, thank you for that. So Tony, I think we've done a good job of discussing the prevailing wage and apprenticeship requirements and the services that you provide, you know, along with encouraging prospective clients to engage us very early in the process. Anything else you want to share before we bring the podcast to a close on this topic?

[00:30:37] Tony Grappone, CPA: No, I think we've covered a lot. I mean, we do anticipate, I did a webinar on PWA last year. We anticipate doing another follow up to that webinar probably this summer.

And so if you're interested in a webinar, feel free to reach out to me and let us know some topics that you'd like us to include in that webinar.

[00:30:55] Michael Novogradac, CPA: Great. Thank you, Tony. I will include your contact information in today's show notes. I'll also include links to the podcast that Peter and I recorded last week about the big, beautiful bill that came out of the House, that's now in the Senate. And some of the adverse effects it would have in the renewable energy space, which we expect to see changes, in the Senate before such a bill's enacted. If it's enacted. as well as send, I'll share information about the Renewable Energy Tax Credit Working Group.

As well as some link to some blog posts about the bill, and then also we'll include a link to that webinar from last year, for those that are interested in that.

Off-Mike

[00:31:47] Michael Novogradac, CPA: With all of that said, Tony, you kicked off an Off-Mike section where we get to shout out, an industry colleague and I really enjoyed that feature that, so thank you for that inspiration.

[00:32:04] Tony Grappone, CPA: You're welcome.

[00:32:05] Michael Novogradac, CPA: This week, who's your industry shout out?

[00:32:08] Tony Grappone, CPA: Great. So sometimes I give the shout out to somebody in the industry outside the firm, and sometimes I shout out to somebody internal. This time I'm going to give a shout out to somebody internal. It's a principal here at Novogradac. His name is Nathan Berrett.

He has taken a very active role with the prevailing wage and apprenticeship, agreed-upon procedure engagements. He's been a big help. He's a subject matter expert, and so feel free to reach out to me. Of course. you know, I’ll gladly talk to you about your PWA engagements. I love this kind of stuff, so I'd love to hear from you, but also feel free to reach out to Nathan Berrett directly.

[00:32:41] Michael Novogradac, CPA: Excellent. And with that, I'll give a shout out as well to Nathan. Thanks for all your work, in this area, all the work you provide, all the services you provide to Novogradac clients. And I'll include Nathan's contact information in today's show notes as well. So thank you, Tony. And to our audience, I'm Mike Novogradac. Thanks for listening and or thanks for watching.

title: Meta signs 20-year nuclear deal to power AI data centres from 2027 | Capacity Media
description:
The agreement, which kicks off from 2027, will provide 1,121 megawatts of emissions-free nuclear energy sourced from the Clinton Clean Energy Centre, an Illinois plant that was due to be closed back in 2017.
Meta claimed that reviving the nuclear plant will preserve more than 1,100 local jobs and contribute $13.5 million annually in tax revenue.
In addition to sourcing nuclear power from Constellation Energy, Meta said it is in “final discussions” with a shortlist of potential projects to meet its 1-4 gigawatt energy target.

text:
The agreement, which kicks off from 2027, will provide 1,121 megawatts of emissions-free nuclear energy sourced from the Clinton Clean Energy Centre, an Illinois plant that was due to be closed back in 2017.

Meta claimed that reviving the nuclear plant will preserve more than 1,100 local jobs and contribute $13.5 million annually in tax revenue.

“It’s clear that there are many nuclear power plants serving the US that need long-term support to help our electricity grids remain reliable as energy needs grow,” the company said in a statement.

“Keeping an existing plant operating will have the same positive effect as adding new clean energy to the grid, and avoid the disruption that has occurred when other nuclear units have retired prematurely.”

Meta, like its hyperscale rivals, has been scouring for access to power to fuel its ongoing digital infrastructure expansion.

The firm recently raised its annual capital expenditure forecast up to $72 billion to fund its data centre ramp-up, with the infrastructure required to support its growing AI services and devices, like its revamped Ray Ban smart glasses.

The social media giant already spent a total of $13.7 billion in Q1, which was driven by investments in servers, data centres, and network infrastructure.

Capacity previously reported that Meta is looking to potentially invest over $200 billion in new data centre campuses, with sites being considered in Louisiana, Wyoming, and Texas, alongside a proposed ~$1 billion facility in Wisconsin.

In addition to sourcing nuclear power from Constellation Energy, Meta said it is in “final discussions” with a shortlist of potential projects to meet its 1-4 gigawatt energy target.

“As we look toward our future energy needs in advancing AI, we recognise the immense value of nuclear power in providing reliable, firm electricity, and the role nuclear projects can have in supporting local economies and strengthening America’s energy leadership,” the company said in a statement.

Meta joins a growing list of businesses looking to nuclear energy to power their data centres, with rivals Microsoft, Google, and Amazon also securing multi-decade deals.

Microsoft also revived a nuclear site previously marked for decommissioning: a plant on the infamous Three Mile Island, back in September.

RELATED STORIES

Meta lifts CapEx to $72bn as AI ambitions fuel data centre push

Why data centres are turning to compact nuclear reactors

authors: Jonathan J. Cooper and Chris Megerian, Jonathan J. Cooper, Chris Megerian
description:
Washington — Elon Musk blasted President Donald Trump's “big, beautiful bill" of tax breaks and spending cuts as a “disgusting abomination" on Tuesday, testing the limits of his political influence as he targeted the centerpiece of Republicans' legislative agenda.
"This massive, outrageous, pork-filled Congressional spending bill is a disgusting abomination.
It's a sharp shift for Musk, the world's richest person, who spent at least $250 million supporting Trump's campaign last year.
He previously pledged to help defeat Republican lawmakers deemed insufficiently loyal to Trump, but now he's suggesting voting them out if they advance the president's legislative priority.
Last month, Musk said he was “disappointed” by the spending bill, a much milder criticism than the broadside he leveled Tuesday.
text:
Washington — Elon Musk blasted President Donald Trump's “big, beautiful bill" of tax breaks and spending cuts as a “disgusting abomination" on Tuesday, testing the limits of his political influence as he targeted the centerpiece of Republicans' legislative agenda.

The broadside, which Musk issued on his social media platform X, came just days after the president gave him a celebratory Oval Office farewell that marked the end of his work for the administration, where he spearheaded the Department of Government Efficiency.

“I’m sorry, but I just can’t stand it anymore,” Musk posted on X. "This massive, outrageous, pork-filled Congressional spending bill is a disgusting abomination. Shame on those who voted for it: you know you did wrong. You know it.”

The legislation, which has passed the House and is currently under debate in the Senate, would curtail subsidies that benefit Tesla, Musk's electric automaker.

The tech billionaire followed his criticism with a threat aimed at Republicans.

“In November next year, we fire all politicians who betrayed the American people,” he wrote in another X post.

It's a sharp shift for Musk, the world's richest person, who spent at least $250 million supporting Trump's campaign last year. He previously pledged to help defeat Republican lawmakers deemed insufficiently loyal to Trump, but now he's suggesting voting them out if they advance the president's legislative priority.

However, it's unclear how Musk will follow through on his criticism. He recently said he would spend “a lot less” on political campaigns, though he left the door open to political involvement "if I see a reason."

The tech titan's missives could cause headaches for Republicans on Capitol Hill, who face conflicting demands from Trump and their party's wealthiest benefactor.

Alex Conant, a Republican strategist, said “it’s not helpful” to have Musk criticizing the legislation, but he doesn’t expect lawmakers to side with Musk over Trump.

“Senate Republicans are not going to let the tax cuts expire,” Conant said. “It just makes leadership’s job that much harder to wrangle the holdouts.”

Trump can change the outcome in Republican primaries with his endorsements, but Musk doesn’t wield that level of influence, Conant said.

“No matter what Elon Musk or anybody else says — and I don’t want to diminish him because I don’t think that’s fair — it’s still going to be second fiddle to President Trump,” said Republican West Virginia Sen. Shelley Moore Capito.

Musk's business interests stand to take a hit if lawmakers approve Trump's bill, which would slash funding for electric vehicles and related technologies. Musk is the chief executive of Tesla, the nation's largest electric vehicle manufacturer, and SpaceX, which has massive defense contracts.

Last month, Musk said he was “disappointed” by the spending bill, a much milder criticism than the broadside he leveled Tuesday.

The budget package seeks to extend tax cuts approved in 2017, during Trump’s first term at the White House, and add new ones he campaigned on. It also includes a massive buildup of $350 billion for border security, deportations and national security.

To defray some of the lost tax revenue to the government and limit piling onto the nation’s $36 trillion debt load, Republicans want to reduce federal spending by imposing work requirements for some Americans who rely on government safety net services.

Musk’s post threw another hurdle in front of Senate Majority Leader John Thune’s already complex task to pass a bill in time for Trump to achieve his goal of signing it by July 4. The South Dakota Republican has few votes to spare in the GOP's slim 53-seat majority.

Two of the Senate’s most fiscally hawkish Republicans quickly backed Musk.

“We can and must do better,” Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul wrote on X. Utah Sen. Mike Lee said “federal spending has become excessive,” adding that it causes inflation and “weaponizes government.”

Still, Trump enjoys fierce loyalty among the GOP base, and in the end, his opinion may be the only one that matters.

White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt played down Musk's criticism.

“The president already knows where Elon Musk stood on this bill,” Leavitt said, and Musk’s post “doesn’t change the president’s opinion.”

The tension in the GOP delighted Democrats, who found themselves in the unlikely position of siding with Musk. Democrats are waging an all-out political assault on GOP proposals to cut Medicaid, food stamps and green energy investments to help pay for more than $4.5 trillion in tax cuts — with many lawmakers being hammered at boisterous town halls back home.

“We’re in complete agreement,” House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries said of Musk. The New York Democratic lawmaker stood alongside a poster-sized printout of Musk's post during a Capitol news conference.

The last time Musk weighed in significantly on legislation, the scenario was far different. His power was ascendant after the election, with Trump joining him for a rocket test in Texas and appointing him to spearhead DOGE.

During the transition period, Musk started whipping up opposition to legislation that would prevent a government shutdown, posting about it repeatedly on X. Trump soon weighed in, encouraging Republicans to back out of a bipartisan deal. Lawmakers eventually patched together a new agreement.

Cooper reported from Phoenix. Associated Press writers Joey Capelletti and Mary Claire Jalonick in Washington contributed reporting.

text:
Sign up for our popular daily email to catch all the latest EV news!

ADS-TEC Energy, a prominent global entity in battery-based energy storage and ultra-fast charging systems, has officially become a member of the Alabama Mobility and Power (AMP) Consortium. This strategic alliance, initially forged by The University of Alabama, Alabama Power, and Mercedes-Benz U.S. International, aims to establish a leading research and development hub for electric vehicle (EV) and mobility innovation.

Key Highlights:

New Membership: ADS-TEC Energy is now a partner in the Alabama Mobility and Power (AMP) Consortium.

Consortium Founders: The AMP Consortium was established by The University of Alabama, Alabama Power, and Mercedes-Benz.

AMP’s Mission: The consortium is dedicated to advancing EV technology, charging infrastructure, battery manufacturing, and power systems.

ADS-TEC’s Contribution: The company will bring its expertise in ultra-fast charging and energy storage technologies.

Local Impact: The partnership will utilize the AMP Center for product testing and validation, bolstering Alabama’s role in transportation and energy.

U.S. Headquarters: ADS-TEC Energy’s U.S. operations for its battery-based, ultra-fast EV charging systems are based in Auburn, Alabama, with expansion anticipated in 2025.

As a member, ADS-TEC Energy will collaborate with other industry, government, and academic partners to propel next-generation mobility solutions. The AMP Center, the consortium’s headquarters, serves as a crucial center for innovation, research, and economic development in areas critical to the EV sector. It also supports vital research and workforce development initiatives, aiming to solidify Alabama’s leadership position in the dynamic transportation and energy landscapes.

Brad Whisenant, consortium development manager at the AMP Center, welcomed ADS-TEC Energy, stating, “Their expertise in ultra-fast charging and energy storage technologies adds a critical dimension to our work advancing the EV infrastructure of tomorrow.” He emphasized that the partnership reinforces a shared commitment to innovation and positions Alabama as a leader in battery and charging technology.

ADS-TEC Energy’s American headquarters for its battery-based, ultra-fast EV charging systems is situated in Auburn, Alabama. The company plans to expand its presence there in 2025 to cater to rising U.S. demand and support its growing installation base. Through its collaboration with the AMP Center, ADS-TEC Energy will leverage the facility for product testing and validation. Furthermore, it will work alongside other consortium members to encourage EV adoption and refine advanced charging techniques throughout Alabama and the wider United States.

Jason Powers, Vice President, North America, for ADS-TEC Energy, remarked on the significance of joining the consortium. He stated, “Alabama is a major player in creating modern mobility and power technologies, developing charging infrastructure and managing power delivery to support large-scale growth in electric vehicles, and the AMP Center is the central hub for much of this innovation.” Powers added that ADS-TEC Energy looks forward to contributing its specialized knowledge in storage systems and advanced charging technologies.

With over a decade of experience in lithium-ion technologies, ADS-TEC Energy develops and manufactures battery storage solutions and fast charging systems, including sophisticated energy management systems. Their battery-based fast-charging technology is particularly noted for enabling ultra-fast EV charging even on weak power grids, all within a very compact design. The company, headquartered in Nürtingen, Germany, has received accolades such as a nomination for the German Future Prize.

title: An innovative "ice battery" system is being used to cool buildings and lower energy costs
description:
"There's about 500,000 pounds of ice created every night," said Holly Paeper, president of Trane Technologies, the company responsible for installing the system it calls an ice battery.
The ice battery system freezes water at night when the cost of electricity is low.
Trane says that this system can lower cooling costs by up to 40%.
So, instead of building more power plants, the focus is on storing energy with a system such as ice batteries.
Shamberger said he sees a world where this system can be used to cool homes.
text:
New York — In the heart of Manhattan, four stories below ground, the iconic Eleven Madison skyscraper is being air-conditioned using ice.

"There's about 500,000 pounds of ice created every night," said Holly Paeper, president of Trane Technologies, the company responsible for installing the system it calls an ice battery. "And to put that into context, think about three city buses full of ice cubes."

The ice battery system freezes water at night when the cost of electricity is low. Then, during the day, when the price is high, the building is cooled with the previous night's ice instead of using expensive electricity. Trane says that this system can lower cooling costs by up to 40%.

"So, when everyone else is using their electricity in the middle of July to cool their building or to cool their homes, it's a big draw on the grid," Paeper said. "This building won't draw from that because it made its ice last night."

Air conditioning makes up about 20% of energy use in homes and businesses worldwide, according to a 2018 report from the International Energy Agency. But on the hottest days, it can account for more than 70% of electricity use during peak hours, per a 2023 IEA report.

"We've done installations at about 4,000 sites globally," Paeper said. "There are six million commercial buildings in the U.S. alone, and a very small fraction of them have installations like this."

The problem that scientists like Dr. Patrick Shamberger are trying to solve isn't an overall lack of energy — it's when too many energy consumers are trying to use electricity at the same time, which puts stress on the grid.

"We don't want to build a whole bunch of excess power plants to just sit around, never turned on until that hot, hot day in August," said Shamberger, an associate professor of materials science and engineering at Texas A&M. "It's a lot of capital investment that doesn't get used."

So, instead of building more power plants, the focus is on storing energy with a system such as ice batteries. But because the process of freezing water uses a lot of energy itself, Shamberger and others are testing new materials that don't need to get as cold as ice, but can still keep buildings cool.

"We take water, we add some other elements and molecules to it," Shamberger explained. "And based on the composition, we can control that temperature basically anywhere we want it, in the zero to 20 C range. And that's important, because what might work great here in Texas, maybe it's not the right temperature to store your heat at if you're in Nevada, or in Wisconsin, say."

According to an analysis released last month by the National Energy Assistance Directors Association, a Washington, D.C.-based energy advocacy group, home electricity bills in the U.S. this summer are expected to rise to an average of $784 for the summer period, from June through September, up 6.2% from last year's projected average of $737.

It marks the highest such average in the 12 years that NEADA has been tracking summer residential cooling.

Shamberger said he sees a world where this system can be used to cool homes.

"Absolutely, yeah...but we're a little bit far out, right?" he said.

name: Clean Energy
title: Meta strikes 20-year nuclear power deal with Constellation Energy
authors: Arcelia Martin, Peter Hall, Jon Hurdle, Inside Climate News
description:
Facebook’s parent company Meta locked in 20 years of nuclear power on Tuesday from Constellation Energy to help meet the tech giant’s surging energy demand for artificial intelligence and its other power-intensive computing needs.
Google signed the first corporate agreement to purchase nuclear energy from multiple small modular reactors (SMRs) developed by Kairos Power in October.
Microsoft entered into a power purchase agreement with Constellation in September to restart the energy company’s Three Mile Island nuclear unit in Pennsylvania.
Constellation’s Clinton Clean Energy Center, about 160 miles southwest of Chicago, was slated to close in 2017 after years of financial losses.
A coalition of large energy users like Amazon, Google, Dow and Meta pledged in March to triple global nuclear energy capacity by 2050.
text:
This article originally appeared on Inside Climate News, a nonprofit, non-partisan news organization that covers climate, energy and the environment. Sign up for their newsletter here.

Facebook’s parent company Meta locked in 20 years of nuclear power on Tuesday from Constellation Energy to help meet the tech giant’s surging energy demand for artificial intelligence and its other power-intensive computing needs.

“Securing clean, reliable energy is necessary to continue advancing our AI ambitions,” Urvi Parekh, head of global energy at Meta, said in a statement.

The agreement, which calls for Constellation to provide Meta with 1.1 gigawatts of power from its Clinton Clean Energy Center in Illinois, is the latest in a slew of deals tying large tech companies to nuclear energy.

Google signed the first corporate agreement to purchase nuclear energy from multiple small modular reactors (SMRs) developed by Kairos Power in October. Amazon anchored a $500 million investment into X-energy Reactor Co.’s research and development of SMRs and is working with Dominion Energy to advance nuclear development in Virginia.

Microsoft entered into a power purchase agreement with Constellation in September to restart the energy company’s Three Mile Island nuclear unit in Pennsylvania. The 20-year deal is slated to contribute to Microsoft’s goal of matching the power its data centers use with carbon-free energy.

Constellation’s Clinton Clean Energy Center, about 160 miles southwest of Chicago, was slated to close in 2017 after years of financial losses. But a zero-emission credit program saved the plant after legislation in Illinois provided financial support into mid-2027.

The agreement announced Tuesday with Meta takes effect in June 2027, when the state’s taxpayer credit program expires. It essentially replaces the credit program and ensures long-term operations of the plant without ratepayer support, according to Constellation.

“This partnership keeps Clinton at the forefront of clean energy while securing jobs and driving local growth,” said Illinois state Rep. Sally Turner, a Republican representing the 44th district, which includes Clinton. “It’s the kind of smart, private investment that strengthens communities without adding taxpayer burden.”

The Clinton power purchase agreement is set to preserve more than 1,000 local jobs and deliver $13.5 million in annual tax revenue, according to the Baltimore-based energy company. Bobby Wendell, an official at a unit of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, said in a statement that the agreement will deliver a “stable work environment” for workers at the plant.

The Energy Center generates enough clean electricity to power some 800,000 homes, according to Constellation. The deal with Meta will relicense and continue the operations in Clinton, while expanding its output by 30 megawatts from its current 1,121 megawatts. The financial details of the deal between Meta and Constellation were not disclosed.

The power purchase agreement comes as nuclear regains traction. Some see the energy source as an answer for the increasing power demands from data centers and AI as long as the technology can scale.

A coalition of large energy users like Amazon, Google, Dow and Meta pledged in March to triple global nuclear energy capacity by 2050. Financial institutions like Bank of America, Citi, Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley also endorsed the commitment for nuclear expansion.

Constellation President and CEO Joe Dominguez said the deal with Meta ensures prior mistakes aren’t repeated by allowing a valuable energy plant to shut down as demand soars.

“Sometimes the most important part of our journey forward is to stop taking steps backwards,” Dominguez said.

name: American Energy
title: Meta's nuclear deal signals AI's growing energy needs - Yahoo Finance
description:
Meta's deal to help revive an Illinois nuclear power plant was one way of signaling that the parent company of Facebook and Instagram is preparing for a future built with artificial intelligence.
Meta's 20-year deal with Constellation Energy follows similar maneuvers from Amazon, Google and Microsoft, but it will take years before nuclear energy can meet the tech industry's insatiable demand for new sources of electricity.
AI uses vast amounts of energy, much of which comes from burning fossil fuels, which causes climate change.
Renewable energy sources such as solar and wind account for about 24% of data center power in the U.S., while nuclear comprises about 15%, according to the IEA.
It will take years before enough climate-friendlier power sources, including nuclear, could start slowing the expansion of fossil fuel power generation.
text:
Meta's deal to help revive an Illinois nuclear power plant was one way of signaling that the parent company of Facebook and Instagram is preparing for a future built with artificial intelligence.

Meta's 20-year deal with Constellation Energy follows similar maneuvers from Amazon, Google and Microsoft, but it will take years before nuclear energy can meet the tech industry's insatiable demand for new sources of electricity.

AI uses vast amounts of energy, much of which comes from burning fossil fuels, which causes climate change. The unexpected popularity of generative AI products over the past few years has disrupted many tech companies' carefully laid plans to supply their technology with energy sources that don't contribute to climate change.

Even as Meta anticipates more nuclear in the future, its more immediate plans rely on natural gas. Entergy, one of the nation’s largest utility providers, has been fast-tracking plans to build gas-fired power plants in Louisiana to prepare for a massive Meta data center complex.

Is the U.S. ready for nuclear-powered AI?

France has touted its ample nuclear power — which produces about 75% of the nation's electricity, the highest level in the world — as a key element in its pitch to be an AI leader. Hosting an AI summit in Paris earlier this year, French President Emmanuel Macron cited President Donald Trump’s “drill baby drill” slogan and offered another: “Here there’s no need to drill, it’s just plug baby plug.”

In the U.S., however, most of the electricity consumed by data centers relies on fossil fuels — burning natural gas and sometimes coal — according to an April report from the International Energy Agency. As AI demand rises, the main source of new supply over the coming years is expected to be from gas-fired plants, a cheap and reliable source of power but one that produces planet-warming emissions.

Renewable energy sources such as solar and wind account for about 24% of data center power in the U.S., while nuclear comprises about 15%, according to the IEA. It will take years before enough climate-friendlier power sources, including nuclear, could start slowing the expansion of fossil fuel power generation.

A report released by the U.S. Department of Energy late last year estimated that the electricity needed for data centers in the U.S. tripled over the past decade and is projected to double or triple again by 2028 when it could consume up to 12% of the nation’s electricity.

Why does AI need so much energy?

It takes a lot of computing power to make an AI chatbot and the systems they're built on, such as Meta's Llama. It starts with a process called training or pretraining — the “P” in ChatGPT — that involves AI systems “learning” from the patterns of huge troves of data. To do that, they need specialized computer chips — usually graphics processors, or GPUs — that can run many calculations at a time on a network of devices in communication with each other.

title: Meta becomes the latest big tech company turning to nuclear power for AI needs | AP News
description:
The investment with Meta will also expand the output of a Constellation Energy Illinois nuclear plant.
Three Mile Island, located on the Susquehanna River just outside Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, was the site of the nation’s worst commercial nuclear power accident in 1979.
Also last fall, Amazon said it was investing in small nuclear reactors, two days after a similar announcement by Google.
Additionally, Google announced last month that it was investing in three advanced nuclear energy projects with Elementl Power.
Last year, 25 states passed legislation to support advanced nuclear energy, and lawmakers this year have introduced over 200 bills supportive of nuclear energy, according to the trade association Nuclear Energy Institute.
text:
WASHINGTON (AP) — Meta has cut a 20-year deal to secure nuclear power to help meet surging demand for artificial intelligence and other computing needs at Facebook’s parent company.

The investment with Meta will also expand the output of a Constellation Energy Illinois nuclear plant.

The agreement announced Tuesday is just the latest in a string of tech-nuclear partnerships as the use of AI expands. Financial details of the agreement were not disclosed.

Constellation’s Clinton Clean Energy Center was actually slated to close in 2017 after years of financial losses but was saved by legislation in Illinois establishing a zero-emission credit program to support the plant into 2027. The agreement deal takes effect in June of 2027, when the state’s taxpayer funded zero-emission credit program expires.

With the arrival of Meta, Clinton’s clean energy output will expand by 30 megawatts, preserve 1,100 local jobs and bring in $13.5 million in annual tax revenue, according to the companies. The plant currently powers the equivalent of about 800,000 U.S. homes. George Gross, professor of electrical and computer engineering at the University of Illinois. estimates that 30 additional megawatts would be enough to power a city with about 30,00 residents for one year.

“Securing clean, reliable energy is necessary to continue advancing our AI ambitions,” said Urvi Parekh, Meta’s head of global energy.

Surging investments in small nuclear reactors comes at a time when large tech companies are facing two major demands: a need to increase their energy supply for AI and data centers, among other needs, while also trying to meet their long-term goals to significantly cut greenhouse gas emissions.

Constellation, the owner of the shuttered Three Mile Island nuclear power plant, said in September that it planned to restart the reactor so tech giant Microsoft could secure power to supply its data centers. Three Mile Island, located on the Susquehanna River just outside Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, was the site of the nation’s worst commercial nuclear power accident in 1979.

Also last fall, Amazon said it was investing in small nuclear reactors, two days after a similar announcement by Google. Additionally, Google announced last month that it was investing in three advanced nuclear energy projects with Elementl Power.

U.S. states have been positioning themselves to meet the tech industry’s power needs as policymakers consider expanding subsidies and gutting regulatory obstacles.

Last year, 25 states passed legislation to support advanced nuclear energy, and lawmakers this year have introduced over 200 bills supportive of nuclear energy, according to the trade association Nuclear Energy Institute.

Advanced reactor designs from competing firms are filling up the federal government’s regulatory pipeline as the industry touts them as a reliable, climate-friendly way to meet electricity demands from tech giants desperate to power their fast-growing artificial intelligence platforms.

Still, it’s unlikely the U.S. could quadruple its nuclear production within the next 25 years, like the White House wants. The United States lacks any next-generation reactors operating commercially and only two new large reactors have been built from scratch in nearly 50 years. Those two reactors, at a nuclear plant in Georgia, were completed years late and at least $17 billion over budget.

Additionally, Gross recommends that the U.S. invest more in the transmission grid that moves that power around.

“That’s my biggest concern,” Gross said, adding that spending on the grid has actually fallen off in recent years, despite the voracious demand for energy.

Amazon, Google and Microsoft also have been investing in solar and wind technologies, which make electricity without producing greenhouse gas emissions.

Shares of Constellation Energy Corp., based in Baltimore, were flat Tuesday.

Here are the key takeaways: 🌡 The assessment identified 115 risks from projected changes in climate conditions, including in energy, transport, communications, water security, public health, food production and supply, and ecosystems. ⚡ 🌊 The significant risks identified by the report as requiring urgent action within the next five years are: 1) The risk of disruption and damage to communications and, energy distribution infrastructure due to extreme wind, and; 2) The risk of disruption and damage to buildings and transport infrastructure due to extreme wind, coastal erosion and coastal flooding. ☀ Additional significant risks that should be prioritised for further investigation in the next five years include risks to the built environment and human health from flooding and heat. You can read more about the National Climate Change Risk Assessment here: https://lnkd.in/eKPJ7QjZ.
